Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop will explore important questions about inclusion in engineering in order to set up a research agenda. The goal will be to identify current barriers that may be keeping people out of engineering. As well as to identify best practices for making sure that the potential talent pool for engineering is fully included. The workshop will include panels and roundtables with faculty members in Engineering and in Sciences, Technology and Society (STS) to facilitate sharing of expertise between the two fields. Focuses of the workshop will include the (1) perceived climate of engineering in past, present, and future work and educational spaces of engineering; and (2) the inclusion of people seen as different and lessons learned from diversity initiatives. This research will be of interest to instructors, advisors, researchers, administrators, professionals, community members, industry and prospective engineers.

The PIs and workshop participants will bring complementary expertise in engineering, diversity initiatives, science of broadening participation and STS to bear on an agenda-setting meeting on inclusion in engineering. Discussions between faculty members from both STS and engineering drawn from diverse disciplines and institutions, and from across the United States, will allow exploration of a broad range of diversity of trajectories in non-discrimination policies and practices. These may be relevant for inclusion of those with other invisible identities, such as religious affiliation, veteran status, and many disabilities, and contribute to increasing the pool of engineering talent. The participants' perspectives will help provide a foundation for developing new tools for measuring the impact of promising practices on diverse engineers' recruitment, retention, performance, creativity and engagement. The interdisciplinary network of engineering and STS faculty fostered by this workshop will be well-positioned to engage in future more expansive collaborative research in the science of broadening participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to assess the engineering environment for LGBTQ individuals, a workshop took place at Georgia Tech on March 1st and 2nd 2018 and was attended by 14 engineering, humanities, and social science faculty from across the United States. The workshop produced valuable and striking insights especially with regards to the participants themselves. Faculty involved remarked that the workshop was an unusually authentic conversation across disciplinary boundaries between engineering on the one hand and social sciences and humanities on the other. Faculty were overwhelmingly members of the LGBTQ community and most were in senior positions allowing participants to be vulnerable and open with each other. This community of practice looks forward to working together going forward and discussed opportunities for blended work across the disciplines. There was consensus that LGBTQ inclusion is both a worthwhile goal in its own right, and that it can and should be a springboard for other forms of diversity, rather than an alternative to it. A graduate student in STS was supported by the project and was engaged in the planning, coordination and synthesis of the workshop.

 

This workshop highlighted the quest for homogeneity vs. diversity in engineering and the importance of intersectional identities. Faculty involved remarked that the workshop was an unusually authentic conversation across disciplinary boundaries between engineering on the one hand and social sciences and humanities on the other. Several actions were suggested to enhance LGBTQ inclusion in engineering: Have diversity statements in classroom and lab documentation; Participate in safe space training, Collaborate across disciplines to integrate social science and humanities with engineering topics in research and courses; Collaborate with local activist groups in courses or as seminars and workshops; Institute ally training workshops at society conferences; Work to change assumptions about a social/technical binary where a focus on cultural and social contexts does not make engineering courses “less technical”; Be a part of more fundamental critiques of engineering education: who defines merit, why is homogeneity prized, and how can the values of engineering better engage questions of justice? This workshop advocates creative engineering education through inclusion and diversity at large, especially inclusion of individuals with invisible identity (or identities), such as (but not limited to) LGBTQ identity, veteran status, religion, disease, anxiety or any form of impairment or disability.

 

The workshop was featured in the Georgia Tech monthly magazine (Th Whistle, Vol. 43, n. 9). The special issue of Georgia Tech College of Engineering entitled "Engineering for A to Z" feauted the workshop at letter I, which was for inclusion.
